Thank you for your welcome.
And particularly thank you for taking part
in Mencar Cymru a Mencar Cerdigion's
Oral History project,
which is being funded by the Heritage Lottery.
Right, I think we'll move on to Bethan's first question.
Can you tell us about your early life?
I was born in Cerdigion in Pembrin,
near Pembrin Beach,
between Llangrannog and Tresaith.
I was in a family of two brothers,
and my father was a sea captain,
which was the tradition in Cerdigion in those days.
I went to school then in Penmarla School,
which was a school covering Sarnay and Tresaith
and part of Llangrannog.
It was run by Mr. Ivar Isaac at the time.
The school was 70 pupils at that time.
Sadly, by today it's closed.
But we had a good education,
and after passing the 11 plus,
which was a bit of a drag in those days,
I went to a Cerdigion grammar school in those days.
The headmaster was the famous Tom Evans.
I got my O and A levels,
and then I went to Cardiff University,
the University College of Wales in Cardiff in those days,
to study social science and social work.
I was the first pupil of Cardigion grammar school
to go to college to do that subject,
if not possibly the first in Cerdigion in those days.
Six of us were doing the course in the 50s.
Only six of us were doing a degree course.
There were others doing diploma, but six of us.
Today there must be hundreds doing the courses up and down.
An interesting course took me to placements
in St David's Hospital, Cardiff,
and I was sent by the professor,
who by the way was a refugee from Germany,
who had taken hands with Adolf Hitler at Berlin University,
that he had to leave his family behind
and never saw them again to come to Wales,
and became Professor Weisman, became Professor in Cardiff in those days.
He sent me to Ely, which is in the news this morning,
and I enjoyed my placement there,
dealing with, believe it or not, dealing with unmarried mothers,
which was a very sensitive issue
because there was a big finer report out
giving status and help to unmarried mothers.
So I was part of that early project in Ely, I can claim that,
and I found people very welcome.
They were very caring people,
and cared for their families,
and met a lot of people in Ely that I admire very greatly.
I also had the pleasure of going to Ely Hospital,
which was a contact with a large hospital
for mental handicap in those days.
Later there was a sad report from Ely Hospital,
which caused the legislation
that moved people of mental handicap out of these large hospitals,
overcrowded hospitals, into the community.
When I returned to Ceredigion in 1969,
that legislation was pivotal
to all the work we did as local authorities afterwards.
I came back to Swansea.
I was appointed mental health social worker in Swansea
and social worker for the elderly in Swansea West,
which included the beautiful part of Swansea,
the mumbles, and I enjoyed my time there.
I saw big developments there, housing,
and changes in patterns of care as well,
were developed in Swansea.
Quite a progressive authority in those days.
But in 1969 I applied to come back to my home county
as the county mental health officer in 1969.
Was that Ceredigion then?
It was known then as Cwngor Sir Abertawe.
Cardiganse County Council in 1969.
I was the county mental health officer, the senior,
and I had four or five staff under me.
Where were you based then?
I was based in Aberystwyth, where we came to live in Aberystwyth.
Our two children were born in Aberystwyth.
In 1969, mental handicap was part of mental health in those days.
We had assessments by Dr Edwards, a deputy medical officer of health.
The famous Dr Morgan Watkin was the medical officer of health,
and he had an interest in mental handicap.
Dr Edwards, the deputy, made all the assessments out in the community in those days,
because we were now bringing back from hospitals in north Wales and south Wales,
we were bringing back mental handicap young people back into the county.
Of course they were calling for mental handicap then,
but that's changed now to learning disabilities.
